title: emma coronel aispuro el chapo guzman mexico
story: Heres our lowdown on the American-born beauty queen who went on to marry one of the worlds most notorious drug lords.Emma Coronel Aispuro married Mexican drug baron Joaquin El Chapo Guzman in .She was born on July , , in Calornia, US, and is believed to have got married on her th birthday.Emma is a former beauty queen who often shares pictures of herself online.She is a Mexican-American, the daughter of Inés Coronel Barreras, a cattle rancher, and Blanca Estela Aispuro Aispuro.Her rancher father is said to have cultivated marijuana and opium poppies and her uncle is slain drug kingpin Igancio Nacho Coronel, an important member of the Sinaloa Cartel and one of El Chapos most trusted men.El Chapo is said to have fallen in love with Emma Coronel when he saw her at a beauty pageant in the Mexican state of Durango in .She was competing in the local Coffee and Guava Festival in , when she was just  and El Chapo exerted his influence to ensure the girl won.El Chapo,  at the time, wooed the young Coronel, who eventually married him on her th birthday.In an interview with the LA Times she said: I would say what won me over was his way of talking, how he treated me, the way we began to get along - first as friends and from that came everything .He tends to win over people by his manner of being, of acting, the way he treats people in general.Joaquin Guzman is a Mexican drug kingpin known as El Chapo - which means shorty in English - due to his short stature.He is accused of running a drug empire that matched Pablo Escobars.He was arrested in Mexico on February , , but escaped from prison on July , .He was caught early in  and was extradited to the US in January .His trial began in New York on November , .He was accused of running the worlds biggest drug cartel and spending  years smuggling over  tons of cocaine into the US.Emma attended almost all of her husbands pre-trial hearings to wave and blow kisses to him, as she has not been allowed to visit him in jail.On February ,  the drug lord was found him guilty of all the counts against him.He will be sentenced on June .Emma reportedly burst into tears in court as the verdict was read.After the jury left the room, El Chapo and Emma put their hands to their hearts and gave each other the thumbs up sign.Coronel gave birth to twin girls in , when she was .Their fathers name was left blank on the birth certicate because there was a million bounty on his head at the time.The children were born in LA and are American citizens. The fourth season of the hit Netflix show was released on the streaming service on November , .In the latest series, the show explored the modern drug wars in Mexico in which El Chapo was a key figure.Mexican actor Alejandro Edda played the gang boss in the show alongside stars Michael Pena and Diego Luna.

title: bbc empire undermines free press
story: Yet the Beeb’s empire-building now threatens to cut off the leblood of our democracy — by undermining a free Press, nationally and locally.The Cairncross Review, a new Government-backed report into the future of UK journalism, deals with the growing danger posed by tech giants Google and Facebook.Remarkably, these mega-s rip off and reproduce news stories from outlets such as The Sun without paying a penny for the privilege.Then they make billions out of ads on “their” news pages.Dame Frances Cairncross thinks Google and Facebook should be regulated to help counter “fake news” and “nudge people towards news of high quality”.Yet her report also had to confront the role of the sainted BBC in helping to undermine the major source of “news of high quality” — national and local newspapers, in print and online.Jeremy Wright, Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, is apparently far from committed to adopting all the Cairncross recommendations and he needs to get a grip on this urgently.The BBC is powerful and persuasive but it should not frighten Cabinet ministers.Dame Frances concludes that broadcasting regulator Ofcom should mount an inquiry into the market impact of BBC News on commercial news providers and local publishers.She says the BBC should “think more carefully about how its news provision can act as a complement, rather than a substitute, for private news provision”.Some of us might put it in less genteel terms. The BBC — fuelled by £billion of public money — has expanded into a state-backed media monster encroaching on areas that should be none of its business, from trivial “clickbait” stories to lestyle advice.After all, the BBC Charter states that it should “provide impartial news and information to help people understand  the world around them. It should offer depth and analysis not widely available from other UK news providers”.Somewhere, this has gone very wrong.It churns out so much stuff online that it could be renamed the British Publishing Corporation.In the process, the monster is devouring the market for everything from local newspapers to gossip websites.Why does “our” national broadcaster now feel obliged to publish “news” stories such as the classic “Serial poopers: What makes people poop in public ” The BBC is also hopelessly addicted to pumping out recipes. Type in “spaghetti bolognese” on Google and the first result that s is from BBC Good Food — a commercial site that trades on the broadcaster’s brand.Why is the BBC even in the already-crowded recipe market  Never heard the one about “too many cooks” By stretching its insensitive tentacles into local areas from its London and Salford HQs, the BBC has contributed to wrecking the local and regional Press, longstanding voices of real communities.At least  local and regional titles have closed since , as circulation halved from .million weekly in  to .million in .Since , the number of regional journalists has also been halved, to around ,.An estimated  per cent of the country now has no daily or weekly title.A robotic BBC web page is no substitute for local Press coverage of council meetings and court proceedings.And yet the money pours in to fund this expansion way beyond its remit.Last year the BBC spent £million on BBC Online and “Red Button” services. The national and local Press are under siege from the tech giants and their BBC collaborators. But this is about more than newspaper self-interest.The future of dirt-digging journalism and democratic debate is at stake.Cairncross estimates that “legacy newsbrands” — aka national and local newspapers — are responsible for around  per cent of all original news journalism in the UK, more than broadcasters and online-only outlets put together. That seems an underestimate.The role of the Press in reporting the news is not just a matter of historical “legacy”. As one ex-editor of a London local paper observes, “councillors and crooks must surely feel relaxed” without local hacks watching and reporting what they are up to.Every big story of recent years was broken by newspapers, from the fire risk Vauxhall Zafira and how Age UK pushed expensive power deals to OAPsto Philip Green gagging reports of sexual and racial harassment .Even last year’s most popular BBC-based story — the snogging scandal on Strictly Come Dancing — was a Sun on Sunday exclusive, before the BBC did its usual parasitical trick of topping Google searches for articles about “the Strictly Curse”.The newspaper tradition of long-form writing and forensic examination will continue to struggle as the online purveyors suck up adverts for cheap and cheerful clickbait.The print medium remains unmatched for serious analysis.Yet the BBC’s self-aggrandising aim is now to expand its global audience further, rather than meet the needs of the underserved as a public service broadcaster surely should.Thus the social media chief of BBC News, Mark Frankel, boasts of the corporation having on Facebook “the largest news page and total fanbase of any news organisation in the world”.The publicly funded BBC need not care that the tech giants don’t pay for stories, as for them Facebook is just a free publicity funnel.That alliance makes it even harder for the rest of the media to take a stand against being royally ripped off.Auntie is effectively in league with greed-driven tech giants.What of the output of all these BBC s  They claim to be a beacon of liberal ersity.The one thing the BBC can’t tolerate, however, is ersity of opinion.It is a bastion of illiberal luvvie smugness, peddling its elitism as the centre ground, blasting out conformist propaganda in Brexit-bashing  debates and Brexit-bashing comedy shows.Lord Reith, the first BBC chief, wanted the then-monopoly corporation to “inform, educate and entertain” the public, from the point of view of the British Establishment.Reith’s successors might have quite a dferent world view.But the new BBC establishment —  managers paid between £, to £, a year,  on between £, to £, — would love to have a state-backed news monopoly again, educating and informing the ignorant public, whether we like it or not.Those of us who appreciate the importance of a vibrant and erse media to democracy, should tell the BBC to get its tanks off the free Press’s lawn.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: learn from the royals meghan
story: The Duchess of Sussex’s handwritten letter to her estranged father was a sincere attempt by a heartbroken daughter to try to “repair” their relationship.Well, that’s what the PR spin, perhaps engineered by Meghan herself, would like you to think.But then a large chunk of the missive was made public by the loose cannon that is Thomas Markle and the plot rather thickened.Firstly, we know that way back, when she was a struggling actress trying to make her mark in Hollywood, Meghan did a calligraphy course that enabled her to give writing lessons at a local workshop instead of waiting tables between auditions.But who writes to their dad in the precise and elaborately penned style of a wedding invitation Equally, he hasn’t just plain old broken her heart. No, he’s broken it, Mills  Boon style, “into a million pieces”.No one is suggesting that Meghan isn’t upset by the way her father and other off-message relatives have behaved — who wouldn’t be But this supposedly “private” attempt to build bridges lacks authenticity.Decades of dealing with PR spin designed to deflect suspicious journalists away from the real storyhas taught me to trust my gut instinct.And given Thomas’s previous form on speaking to the Press, it’s telling me that Meghan wrote this rather staged letter in the expectation that he would leak it and, therefore, seamlessly allow her to peddle her own narrative while maintaining the cover of the innocent party who has been betrayed by her own father yet again.But Thomas kept the letter under wraps. Until, that is, he was baited in to defending himself against claims made by some of Meghan’s close friends, who spoke anony-mously , about the duchess’s plight to the US-based People magazine.One said: “After the wedding she wrote him a letter. She’s like, ‘Dad, I’m so heartbroken. I love you. I have one father. Please stop victimising me through the media so we can repair our relationship’.”Look, Thomas Markle is by no means blameless. He did a deal with the paparazzi for staged photos, is clearly given to petulance, has only released the parts of the letter that suit him and, as the parent in this scenario, should be the one to stop this tit-for-tat soap opera and just shut the hell up.But equally, any sympathy one might have felt for Meghan in dealing with her off-message family is evaporating fast in the face of such a blatant PR exercise that has her manicured fingers all over it.One of the friends who spoke out has “let it be known” that the duchess herself knew nothing of them speaking to People magazine.Sorry, but I just don’t buy it. Meghan has form for dropping friends like hot potatoesthey displease her, so the notion that those who remain “close” would speak to the Press — anonymously or otherwise — without approval is, to my mind, utter bunkum.Which leads me to conclude that this was a ham-fisted, Hollywood-esque attempt to try to manipulate Press coverage and put a stop to, as her friends put it, the “global bullying” of The Duchess of Sussex. But it has backfired badly.Yes, plenty of the criticism levelled at Meghan is unfair, and some of it is downright offensive.But as the rest of the Royal Family could tell her, they’ve all suffered their share of brickbats over the years but come through it.How  By earning respect through dutul and consistent hard work, not demanding it early doors via an ill-conceived PR initiative.JENNIFER ANISTON has just celebrated her th birthday.Or “poor Jen” as she’s frequently referred to because she’s single and childless which, obviously, is something to be pitied because marriage and giving birth defines us.Meanwhile, back in the real world, the single le appears to suit the fierce Ms A very well indeed.She says she considered her marriages to be successful, but when the end came: “This is our one le and I would not stay in a situation out of fear. Fear of being alone.“To stay in a marriage based on fear feels like you’re doing your one le a disservice.”She’s right, of course. But moving on is far simpler when you don’t have children together.If you do, then taking the decision to break up the family home is a far tougher one.Because your kids only have “one le” too.NOW US teenager Ethan Lindenberger has turned , he has finally had the MMR vaccination while criticising his “anti-vaxxer” movement parents for refusing to give it to him when he was younger.His mother, Jill Wheeler, who believes that vaccinations cause illnesses such as autism, says his decision is “insulting” and a “slap in the face”.Ethan, from Ohio, did his own research into the jab and commented on social media site Reddit, “God knows how I’m still alive” – presumably a reference to the fact that measles can be deadly.He probably swerved it thanks to all the parents who recognise the need for herd immunity and do have their children vaccinated.PARENTS in America say that regular viewing of children’s TV show Peppa Pig is causing their kids to start speaking in a British accent.Many moons ago, I went to collect my youngest from her first day at nursery and was greeted by an excited young assistant who hailed from Valencia.“I didn’t know your daughter could speak Spanish!”“Neither did I,” I replied.Turns out that rather too much time in front of Dora The Explorer had indeed been educational.LUNG cancer screening units are to be offered in supermarket car parks across the UK in an NHS bid to improve early detection rates.This reminds me of when a mobile cervical cancer screening unit was set up in a Birmingham car park in the s and an elderly lady approached the receptionist.She was directed to a curtained booth, given a smear test, then emerged to declare: “I’ve never had to do this to get a bus pass before.”NETFLIX documentary Fyre: The Greatest Party That Never Happened is proof,needed, that all on Instasham etc is not what it seems.The Fyre festival was the brainchild of US “entrepreneur” Billy McFarland, now serving six years in prison for fraud, aided and abettedby a close coterie of consultants, marketeers, media experts andonline “influencers” who helped sell the dream of an exclusive event on a luxury, Bahamian island to unsuspecting, albeit wealthy punters who turned up to find a nightmare of soggy tents, bad food and no headline acts.Among those who appeared in a promotional video and posted the event’s distinctive “orange tile” to their millions of followers to help drive ticket sales were models Bella Hadid and Emily Ratajkowski.Most notably, model Kendall Jenner was paid an eye-watering , via wire transfer for just one post about it to her million-plus followers.It shows with compelling clarity that while the power of A-list, online influence is real, what’s being promoted can sometimesbe a Grade A dud.So, buyer beware of those “influencers” who only post for favours or cash.They’re just the social media version of the old-fashioned freeloader.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says theresa may remainers brexit delay
story: Talk in Brussels is  of a last-minute compromise, perhaps enough to get the PM’s deal over the line. They know No Deal will damage them, Ireland especially. They want the agreement to work.But we must not blink.If Labour and Tory Remainers, even some in the Cabinet, approve a delay to Article  and seize control from the PM on February  it only has upsides for the EU. It can then wait for a much softer Brexit, or none.Tories, on both party wings, should know this: Every alternative to Mrs May’s deal, with appropriate legal adjustment to the Irish backstop, ends in potential catastrophe for their party.Their poll leads over Labour will vanishBrexit is substantially delayed. They will go into a full-throttle reversea second referendum gets the nod. Likewise a feeble “Norway-Plus” non-Brexit or a permanent, restrictive customs union.Or indeedthere’s No Deal chaos, for which they will be blamed.Mrs May, for her country and party, must face down the threats from all  those losing their bottle as the clock ticks down to our  exit on March .If they want to quit they must get on with it. Otherwise they must stop bellyaching, back the PM and let her tease out the legal changes her deal needs.“We all need to hold our nerve,” Mrs May said yesterday. For once, she is dead right.SAJID Javid’s immigration policy threatens to do the reverse of what the public wants.No one will believe we have “taken back control” of our bordersthe Home Secretary relaxes the rules so far that net migration soars.He doesn’t want an arbitrary limit —  we agree there. But lowering thresholds on pay, skills and entry requirements for all migrants, EU and non-EU, is bound to increase totals dramatically.Mr Javid has surrendered to the insatiable appetite of big business for cheap, low-skilled foreign labour which has helped keep pay at rock-bottom levels.But Brexit was an overwhelming demand to reclaim powers for Britain, including over immigration.No one voted for it to hit record levels.TO those now of a certain age, Gordon Banks was a superhero.The  World Cup-winning keeper. The genius whose incredible flying leap somehow kept out that Pele header at Mexico ’ — and whose career-ending eye injury sent millions into mourning.England’s greatest goalie. Maybe the world’s greatest. But a man unfailingly modest and decent to the end.Rest in peace, Banksy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sell brexit down river because scant respect for democracy always going happen anyway
story: And amid all the euphoria, I remember saying to my we: “They won’t let it happen. Somehow, they’ll stop it.” I don’t think I was alone in reckoning that.It’s looking very much like that at the moment, isn’t it  We’re  days away from deadline time, March . But what do you reckon the likelihood is of the deadline being put back  I’ll bet it is.Olly Robbins thinks it’s likely. He’s a civil servant and the Prime Minister’s chief negotiator to the EU. He was overheard jabbering about the whole business in a bar in Brussels. And he saidthere WERE a delay, it would most likely be a long one.We’ll probably all be here this time next year, then, in exactly the same position.By which time the deal will be so watered down, the whole point will have been lost. It’s pretty close to that stage right now.Why has this happened  Because our establishment do not want us to leave. And while they may pay lip service to “respecting the voice of the people”, they don’t remotely mean it. They never did.And so, on the one hand we have establishment voices — Blair, Mandelson, Heseltine — and a growing number of current politicians demanding we must have another vote. Because we got it wrong last time.The European Union has a history of ignoring popular votes and getting countries to run the vote again, after a slew of propaganda about why the people were so wrong.Then, on the other hand, we have a Prime Minister who voted Remain leading our negotiations. And at every stage of the process more and more has been given away.We started from a position of weakness by allowing the EU to dictate the order of the negotiations. So they got to demand things from us — such as extortionate amounts of money — before we even got down to talking about our trading relationship.And at every stage the deal has got weaker. Every time she came back from Brussels, something more had been given away. Until we reach today’s position, where the deal before us isn’t really leaving the EU at all.We’ll still be tied to the customs union for the foreseeable future. We will still have the horrible European Court of Justice telling us what we can and can’t do for another two years.And there are plenty of people who believe that the famous issue of the Northern Ireland backstop is simply an attempt to get us to remain, for ever, inside the customs union.Here’s what I think will happen.Brexit will, in the end, be delayed. And by the time a deal is put before us again — months down the line — it will bear no real resemblance to “leaving the European Union”.And so those of us who have no trust in our liberal establishment, because we know what scant respect it has for democracy, will be able to say: “Told you so. They were never going to let it happen.”Congratulations to young Hartlepool lad Michael Rice for becoming our entrant in the Eurovision Song Contest.He’s singing a ditty called Love Is Really Lovely or something, and will come third from last, just above Kosovo and France.Michael Rice will represent the UK at Eurovision but will probably come third from lastBut bless him, at least he’ll be going.Far left, anti-Semitic bullies have been demanding we boycott the extravaganza because it’s in Israel.A bunch of C-list celebs wrote a letterinsisting we pull out.They said nothing when the contest was held in the repressive Islamic state of Azerbaijan.Good luck, Michael. And enjoy lovely Tel Aviv.In future, eight per cent of people in BBC programmes must be gay.That’s a new target the corporation has set itself.The BBC is trying to represent the country with gay quotas but perhaps they could do better with BrexitYes, I know what you’re thinking. The current number is somewhere in the region of  per cent.But still, this is just the BBC trying hard to represent the country as it is, and we shouldn’t complain.In fact, here’s a few more areas where they might try to better represent the country as it is.Pro-Brexit people on political programmes.A majority voted to leave. title: meghan markle prince harry new home feng shui
story: The Duchess of Sussex, , is a big fan of the ancient belief that arranging furniture in a certain way creates good vibes.She wants its ideas applied to Frogmore Cottage, which is being renovated for her and Prince Harry.Feng shui works by placing items like beds, cookers and desks in “command” positions facing doors.Devotees also keep homes clutter free, do not keep broken goods and insist on sparkling windows.Meghan revealed her love of the art in her lestyle blog The Tig, written when she lived in Canada.The former Suits actress told followers: “The ancient Chinese art of feng shui has been practised for nearly , years.“With so many layers of tradition and technicality, it may seem daunting to introduce to your home aesthetic and ethos.“However, the core of feng shui is about making you feel comfortable and at ease in your home so that it can translate into every aspect of your le — so fret not.”Meghan and Harry, , hope to be in Frogmore Cottage, near Windsor Castle, before the end of next month when their baby is due.The renovations are costing up to £million. title: bobby davro graffiti stoke on trent les dennis
story: The -year-old entertainer’s moniker popped up as graffiti in three places in a five-mile radius.John Green, , who spotted them, said: “Maybe it’s a new artist who gets kicks out of popularising obscure celebrities.“Or maybe Bobby and Les have got together to give each other a career boost.”Comedian Bobby’s name was sprayed around Stoke-on-Trent,  miles from where he grew up in Ashford, Middlesex.Graphic designer John said: “I saw one in an underpass and thought it was quite funny.Then when I spotted another a couple of miles away on a massive billboard, I thought of Les Dennis.“Then a couple of days later I saw a third one in a tunnel. It’s definitely one person.“I don’t knowit’s the same as the Les Dennis one, though. It’s given me a good chuckle. I think this could be the new Banksy.”Family Fortunes host Les, , had his name sprayed across Norwich last November — and said on Twitter: “It wasn’t me.”Bobby told The Sun: “I had hoped I would be up in lights rather than spray paint but I am incredibly flattered to be up there with the greats — Banksy and Les Dennis.“It is just mad what some people do, I’m looking forward to touring Stoke now.”Petty graffiti can be punished by a £ fine, though offenders can be jailed in serious cases.Stoke councillor Anthony Munday said: “Bobby Davro’s telly antics have brought fun to families for generations. title: pm brexit boundaries no deal vote james forsyth
story: The symbolic defeat that MPs inflicted on her Brexit plan on Thursday night has signicantly weakened her negotiating position.The EU doesn’t want to make signicant changes to the backstop. It repeats endlessly that the withdrawal agreement is closed and that it isn’t going to reopen it.When the Brady amendment passed the House of Commons, saying Parliament would accept the dealthe backstop was replaced, the EU responded by saying they didn’t think this Parliament majority was “stable”.Thursday night’s vote helps them make that argument.As one No source laments: “We don’t want to give the Europeans a chance not to engage with us.”I understand that when the Brexit Secretary, Steve Barclay, dined in Brussels this week Sabine Weyand — the EU’s deputy negotiator — spent her time telling him that a customs union was the only major change available to the backstop.The EU think that Corbyn’s support for it means that a customs union could pass Parliament. I am told Barclay attempted to disabuse them of this idea.Mrs May can’t entirely escape blame for this week’s fiasco.No should have made sure that its own MPs were happy with the wording before publishing the motion.“She’s like a football team that can’t string two wins together,” complains one minister.But the Tory Brexit ultras should have paid more heed to the real-world consequences of their actions.Another effect of Thursday night’s defeat for the Government is that it increases the chances of the Cooper amendment passing on February .This would compel the Government to seek an extension to Article Mrs May hasn’t won Parliament’s support for an exit deal by March .One Cabinet minister, with close links to several of the ministers who might quit to ensure this amendment goes through, tells me it is now “much more likely” to pass.This Secretary of State complains that the Government’s defeat “makes it harder to make the argument that we should hold our nerve” as “the best evidence for holding your nerve was that the outcome would be the same as when the Brady amendment went through”.Another minister warns: “If she doesn’t come back with something cooking by the th, there’ll be trouble.”I understand those around Mrs May know they need to have shown progress by the th.One insider tells me: “If the Government doesn’t want Parliament to take control, they need to have a plan.They can’t just sit there for two weeks.”Other Cabinet ministers aren’t so sure Cooper will pass.One tells me: “I don’t think the ministers will resign, andthey don’t resign, then it doesn’t pass.”If Cooper does go through, politics will enter into an even more unpredictable phase. One May Cabinet ally is predicting a general electionthis happens.But it is hard to see how a general election could end in anything other than disaster for the Tories in these circumstances.If Mrs May is forced to ask the EU for an extension but with no Parliamentary agreement in sight, the EU is more likely to offer a long extension than a short one.I understand the view in several EU capitals is that the longer the extension, the more likely it is that the political dynamics in the UK will change.But a long extension would prolong this damaging, political uncertainty.This Government, and this Parliament’s, job is to get Brexit done. Time is running short. Both Parliament and the Government need to get their act together.But it may well be because the NHS – traditionally Labour’s strongest suit – is not the most important issue in politics right now.But that number is down to  per cent this winter, according to the pollster Ipsos Mori.The question now is whether the Tory decision to spend an extra £billion a year on the health service by  leads to a decline in public concern.But in January AE departments recorded their worst waiting times since the figures started being collected in .Matt Hancock, the new Health Secretary, is setting up a new NHS-X unit to try to bring the health service into the digital era, which would help the NHS to better use its resources.There are many things the Tories have to do to win the next election – not least, deliver Brexit – but they must also reassure voters on the NHS.Butthey can be ed they should be subject to the full force of the law.Justice must be done and must be seen to be done.Churchill wouldn’t have been Prime Minister but for the Labour Party’s willingness to serve in a government led by him.When it came to the crucial decision to fight on in , Clement Attlee and Arthur Greenwood, two Labour members of the War Cabinet, were more solid than some of Churchill’s Tory colleagues.But Attlee and Greenwood came from a very dferent Labour tradition to McDonnell: They weren’t Marxists or Trotskyists.There are some Labour MPs who are just not prepared to try to put into power people who are so outside the traditional bounds of the party.One minister likens the coming Tory leadership race to the  Grand National, when a crowded field led to a pile-up at the rd fence and the victory of the - outsider Foinavon.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: life saving transplant operation
story: Transplant patient James Walton, , is only the third person in the UK to undergo the procedure.A genetic condition had left him with heart defects and when its main artery burst, joiner James was told only a new organ would save him and he was put on the urgent transplant list.Just five days later a match was found and James was rushed from his home in Stoke-on-Trent to hospital in Birmingham.Surgeons removed the donor ticker, keeping it alive in a special see-through Heart in a Box.The organ is kept beating with a battery-operated pump and tiny electrical shocks, and has supplies of oxygen, blood and drugs to simulate conditions in the body.Usually transplant organs are kept on ice to preserve them for a limited time, which pits surgeons against the clock.But the revolutionary method that saved James keeps the heart in better condition for longer, lowering risks for the patient.He is now back home with we Kat and three-year-old son after his -hour operation five weeks ago.He said: “As soon as I woke up I felt like a new person. I’ve been given a second le.“Most importantly I can spend time with my little boy.”James was born with Marfan Syndrome which led to major heart surgery, including having a pacemaker fitted.JCB factory worker Kat, , said: “James couldn’t walk more than  yards. He couldn’t play football or go to the park with Jack.“Now he can chase his son around. Jack has got his daddy back.”The op, by surgeon Majid Mukadam, was the first of its kind at Birmingham’s Queen Elizabeth Hospital.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says brexit compromise jeremy corbyn
story: The EU must compromise too.They know they can make firmer legally-binding promises on the hated Irish backstop. Time to offer them up.Brexiteers must then hold their noses and vote for Theresa May’s deal. All other roads lead to catastrophe.They won’t get the backstop removed. We don’t believe they’ll get a No Deal exit either, and eventhey did the short-term chaos would kill their party.Instead Parliament would postpone Brexit, possibly finishing the Tories for a generation. This current purgatory would go on for months longer — maybe long enough for Remainers to reverse the referendum result.The Government would have failed in its only mission. It would instead have undermined our democracy and ensured bitter isions that would never heal.The one person unable to compromise, oddly, is the Prime Minister. Because what Brussels, Labour and Tory Remainers glibly ask of her, a permanent customs union, ALSO wrecks her party and destroys Brexit’s economic case.It was folly to expect the Tory ERG group to vote to “take No Deal off the table” on Thursday night. Logic was on their side, at least.But they need to think hard now how they will feel on March Brexit is put off and they are blamed. If they have opened the door to a toxic, anti-Semitic, anti-Western Labour rabble so crazed by ideology they cannot even allow Winston Churchill’s historic defeat of Nazism to trump his other failings.A party committed to massive tax rises, maybe even a  per cent windfall levy on anyone’s “wealth”. A party led by pension-age Marxist revolutionaries friendly to Putin, Hamas, the IRA and hard-left dictators but hard on private enterprise, job-creation and free speech.We sincerely hope Labour moderates stop dithering and resign to undermine Corbyn and McDonnell. We marvel that so many can still stomach these sinister men poised to do unimaginable harm.But eventhey can’t grasp that, Tory Brexiteers can. And we say this to them:Wake up. Look how close you now are to bringing this calamity about.WILL the Government squander the biggest potential shale gas discovery in our history It is believed there is enough under the East Midlands alone to power Britain cheaply for  years.Yet the Tories are suffocating this new industry at birth by persisting with an absurdly low limit on the level of tremor allowable when drilling. It is hundreds of times weaker than anyone can feel.A Government public information campaign must nail the lies the eco lobby has told to turn Brits off fracking.If Theresa May ever sorts Brexit, she must take charge of it personally.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle acting return the boys and girls guide to getting down
story: The Duchess of Sussex may have given up acting to marry Prince Harry, but her  TV show - The Boys  Girls Guide to Getting Down - has been picked up for film distribution in the US.The tongue-in-cheek show follows -something singles clubbing and partying in LA over the course of a single night.In a far cry from her prim and proper Suits character Rachel Zane, Meghan plays single Dana, who is shown shimmying into a skintight dress before a night out.When her friend, Heather, says she didn’t think Dana was on the hunt for a new man, Dana insists: “I dress this way for me. I’m not looking for a guy tonight. Trust me.”A voiceover explains that Meghan’s character is also jealous of Heather’s ample bust.As Meghan cups her own breasts, the narrator adds: “She’s considering buying a pair for herself.”The two girls then head to a nightclub where Meghan’s character can be seen snorting a suspicious substance.When the show was released in  it only lasted one episode because telly executives decided they did not want a whole series.But Artist Rights Distribution is planning to re-release it as a film later this year, according to the Hollywood Reporter.Shortly after appearing in the racy comedy, Meghan landed the role of Rachel Zane on Suits.She fast became a fan favourite and rumours are swirling she’ll make a cameo in the show’s final season .Suits creator Aaron Korsh is giving nothing away.He told website Popsugar he’d loveshe reprised her role, but he’s “not currently pursuing asking Meghan to leave her position with the royal family and join us”.After seven seasons on the legal drama, Meghans character Rachel Zane made her last appearance in the episode titled Good-Bye in April .Just one month later she tied the knot with Prince Harry at St Georges Chapel in Windsor Castle.The royal couple are now expecting their first child together.

title: brexit trade deal delayed human rights
story: Fiji objected to continuing the current trading arrangements after Brexit because they wanted the EU’s strict human rights standards stripped out.The island nation is the first known country to seek the concession in trade negotiations.And it comes after Trade Secretary Liam Fox admitted human rights had become a sticking point delaying the talks to roll-over some of the EU’s  free trade deals.A secret progress report leaked to The Sun earlier this week revealed that just six of the trade deals are on course to be ready in time for Brexit Day on March .Mr Fox has refused to water down the human rights protections, which ban the trade of any goods made through child labour, forced labour or factories where collective bargaining is barred.Other examples of human rights violations that EU trade deals ban include torture and execution equipment.They also bar trade with countries that undermine democratic, civil and political rights such as the freedom of speech, freedom to protest.Fiji’s objections stalled the negotiations over rolling-over the EU-Pacic trade deal, which also includes Papua New Guinea and will soon be joined by Samoa and the Solomon Islands.But the Department for International Trade has said Fiji’s objections had now been overcome and the terms of the UK-Pacic Economic Partnership Agreementhave been agreed, with a deal expected to be signed “in the coming weeks”.A spokesman said the deal will “include the same commitments to human rights and democracy as our existing EU agreement”.Yesterday Mr Fox said fears of a no deal Brexit have also deterred countries such as South Korea agreeing to roll-over the current EU trading arrangements.The trade deal with South Korea - a major trading partner for Britain - is among nine that have been given an amber warning - meaning talks are currently “off-track”.Red and black warnings are given to  other EU deals, including big trading partners Japan, Turkey and Mexico, which are given no chance of being completed by Brexit Day.They are classed either “signicantly off-track” or “not possible to be completed by March ”.

title: brexit politicians not how you
story: NewsopinionDear politicians: this is not how you do BrexitThe only job theyre doing well is demonstrating the depths of their incompetenceShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  FEB Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is possible, with a week and a swimming pool and nice weather, to teach a toddler to swim. With a little bit of instinct, a flotation device and constant repetition of hand movements, a miniature psychopath can be taught something new. Youll end up a sunburned prune, of course, and any attempt to leave the pool will be greeted with screaming, but it will be instructive to all concerned. When the holiday is over and you leave the pool and sunshine to turn your attention once again to the news-vacuum that is Brexit, you may wonder which alternative dimension all the grown-ups were sucked into, and why more Ritalin was not prescribed to those currently smashing the country to pieces.Because with  working days until Brexit -  in Northern Ireland, where presumably the inhabitants will be spending the March bank holiday doomsday prepping - our political class is floundering as only those who have unwisely put bricks in their pockets and jumped in the deep end can do.Theyre not panicking. Theyre too stupid for that. Instead theyre merrily trying to drown each other in the mistaken belief that,they are the last one left, they will own a swimming pool. They have failed to note this ownership will last for all of a second before their vision darkens permanently, because they did not think it through before immersing themselves in something they were entirely unqualied to deal with. The Conservative Party is doing just as it has for the past  years, and expending all its energies negoatiating with a fringe so deranged even David Bowie in the depths of an LSD bender would dismiss it as ridiculous.The Labour Party still cant agree with itself on what day of the week it is. This is possibly because it is worried some of the days are Jewish, and possibly because some members accuse others of not believing strongly enough in St Jeremy of Islington. Theresa May is ignoring Parliament, same as she did while Home Secretary, and Parliament is mostly ignoring her. Nigel Farage has not formed a new party, but is pretending he has until it fails when hell say it was nothing to do with him.Meanwhile Tony Blairs famed Third Way project is alive and well, as Left and Right prove themselves to be as statesmen-like as chimpanzees in a shit-flinging contest. The true story always lies in the things that arent said - and in the case of Brexit it is the ever-decreasing circle of campaigning wingnuts available to speak publicly about what a great idea Brexit is.On June , , you couldnt throw a brick without hitting a politician or commentator prepared to wax lyrical about sunlit uplands, the easiest trade deals in history, and how the EU needed us more than we need them. Today youve got to hunt through the back of a contacts book to find a backbencher who wants publicity more than respect, and there seems to be rather fewer of those desperate beasts than there used to be. Count the pro-Brexit public faces, and ask yourself whether theyre eating each other or pretending to be invisible. How many no longer answer their phones, and how many are no longer invited to speak because they lie.Somethings happening to them. Are they being infected with common sense, or a particularly-specic plague that targets the gobshite gene  The only job any of them are doing well is demonstrating the depth of their incompetence. How to argue with each other while disaster looms, how to put ideology above practicality, how to govern like goons.Meanwhile the country is in a meat grinder, relentlessly turning -odd years of legislation into so much indigestible gristle. A total of , pieces of EU laws and regulations - those things the Leave campaign said we didnt need - are being put into UK law, because it turns out we need them.Of the  new bills needed for Brexit, just  have been passed. To exit without a deal and go to WTO rules, we need  bills,  new processes,  new IT systems,  new laws to be passed by the Irish government and  pieces of secondary legislation of which just  have been approved. And all while the Article  clock the Leavers demanded is ticking down, even though they promised before the vote that theyd never start it without a plan.But hey, we dont need to extend Article , say the chimps. Lets go on holiday instead.This is all happening, one assumes, in the belief thatthey drag it out long enough the rules of natural justice will be bent so far out of shape, and apply so much force against the immovable Northern Irish border where the old bomb-makers are even now cracking their knuckles, that Mother Nature will be under pressure to let them to evolve gills overnight.They dont seem to have noticed that, in instances of stupidity and incompetence, Mother Nature prefers to let people die. Evolution works through failure, not wishing.As a drinking game, Brexit is unbeatable. And probably deadly. As entertainment, it lacks belly-laughs unless you wish to include guessing the calorie content of Brexit-brayers. Francois would be as fatty as underdone pork crackling, but is Mogg a form of human celery which takes more energy to digest than it delivers But as an example of good governance - of careful thought, wisdom, foresight and empathy for others - Brexit is a swirling, soul-sucking vortex of immense disappointment.

title: alesha macphail accused 16 sent
story: NewsAlesha MacPhail suspect, , sent bad joke Snapchat selfie saying "Found the guy whos done it"The teenage boy denies raping and murdering Alesha, whose body was discovered in woodland on the Isle of Bute, Scotland, on July  last yearShareBySophie EvansLaura Paterson:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAlesha MacPhail was found dead in woodland on the Isle of Bute, Scotland, on July  last year "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boy accused of murdering Alesha MacPhail sent a Snapchat video of himself to pals before saying: Found the guy whos done it, a court has heard. The -year old, who cannot be named for legal reasons, denies abducting, raping and murdering six-year-old Alesha on the Isle of Bute, Scotland.The schoolgirls body was discovered in woodland on the island in the Firth of Clyde on July  last year, and jurors have heard she had  separate injuries.This morning, the High Court in Glasgow was told that the boy - who cannot be named for legal reasons - was chipping in with rumours and speculation about what may have happened to Alesha on a Snapchat group chat.Giving evidence, a -year-old girl - said to also be a member of the chat - told jurors the teenager shared a video of himself with the group.  The footage showed his body in a mirror, but not his face, she said.She added that the accused then sent a message to the group, reading: Found the guy who’s done it”, which she thought was a bad joke.The girl said: At the time I didnt think much of it. It was a joke, a bad joke, but then when I heard he got arrested I thought more about it. She then reported the video to police, the court heard.The witness, described as a close friend of the boy, can also not be identied due to her age, and gave evidence at the court from behind a screen. Jurors had earlier heard that a kne was found on the shore opposite the Isle of Bute home where Alesha was allegedly taken from. The youngster had been staying in the house her father shared with her grandparents when she was reported missing shortly after am.  Her body was discovered hours later. Coastguard volunteer Peter Morrison, , from Rothesay, told the High Court that he was called out to carry out a shoreline search at .am. Opposite the house where Alesha had been staying, he found what looked like a kitchen kne, jurors were told.Mr Morrison said he did not touch the kne, which he believed had been in the sea and left onshore by the receding tide. But he noted its location before continuing to search for Alesha. He later told police, who cordoned off the area, it was said.The court also heard from Police Sergeant Anthony Hannah, who said he arranged for photos to be taken and for the recovery of the kne. He also said he threw a separate item of evidence - a black hooded top - in a skip believing it was not relevant to the murder inquiry.  Mr Hannah said the item of clothing, found by a dog walker on the beach, was later retrieved on the instruction of detectives. Today is the trials fth day of proceedings. The accused denies abducting Alesha, raping and murdering her, and attempting to hide evidence. He has lodged a special defence blaming Toni McLachlan - the girlfriend of Aleshas father, Robert MacPhail - for the killing. The trial, before judge Lord Matthews, continues.

Another pal of the boy - a -year-old girl - said Aleshas disappearance was discussed in a Snapchat group of around  friends on July . The youngster had been staying in the house her father shared with her grandparents when she was reported missing shortly after am that day. Her body was found hours later in a wooded area on the island. Giving evidence, the witness said the accused sent a video of himself in the mirror, showing his top half, but not his face to the group chat that afternoon. This was followed by the message, found the guy whos done it, she said. The witness said she thought it was a bad joke. However, she later told police when it emerged an arrest had been made in the murder inquiry.  She said the boy also sent messages to the group saying what he thought couldve happened and how couldhave got out the house without anybody noticing in the house. She agreed other people in the group were contributing gossip, rumour and speculation. Questioned by Brian McConnachie QC, for the accused, she said at the time it was posted she was not aware Alesha had been murdered. She also agreed others were making comments in poor taste. He asked her: Ifhad not been arrested, you would have continued to think this was a bad joke  Yeah, she replied.  Earlier, the court had heard a kne was found on the shore opposite the home where the Alesha was allegedly taken from. Coastguard volunteer Peter Morrison, , from Rothesay, said he was called out to carry out a shoreline search at .am. Opposite the house where the youngster had been staying, he found what looked like a kitchen kne, jurors were told. Mr Morrison said he did not touch the kne, which he believed had been in the sea and left onshore by the receding tide. But he noted its location before continuing to search for Alesha. He later told police, who cordoned off the area, it was said.  The teenager accused over Aleshas death denies abducting her, raping and murdering her, and attempting to hide evidence. He has lodged a special defence blaming Toni McLachlan - the girlfriend of Aleshas father, Robert MacPhail - for the killing. On Wednesday, Ms McLachlan told jurors she loved Alesha and had nothing to do with her death. The trial, before judge Lord Matthews, continues.

title: brian reade doff your cap
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: Doff your cap to the ruling class or be dismissed as a Poundland LeninBritain loves a bit of black and white thinking - as the outrage over John McDonnells comments display - and this attitude isnt doing us many favoursShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  FEB NewsopinionBrits reaction to criticism of the establishment - including Winston Churchill - is a telling sign "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn McDonnell felt the full force of an enraged British establishment after calling Winston Churchill a villain. Or rather, when asked in a quickfire QAhe was a hero or a villain, he answered “Tonypandy – villain”. As in, it was far from heroic behaviour to set the army on striking miners, killing one of them and injuring . As it was putting troops on the streets of shyLiverpool to kill two people during the  transport strike.Or dismiss hunger marchers as shirkers, send the Black and Tans to murder the Irish as Colonial Secretary in the s, claim no wrong was done to “American Red Indians” or Australian aborigines by the white man and that British imperialismwas a good and natural thing as “a higher-grade race” could lead the “primitive” and “subject” races.Heroic in defeating the Nazis  Undoubtedly. But villainous at times where No question.However, such balanced thinking is frowned upon in this country. The Queen Mother, “Gawd bless ’er”, was another old bigot who supported apartheid, refused to call Rhodesia “Zimbabwe” and claimed the EU wouldn’t work because “Huns, wops and dagos” never get on. But say anything against our th-century Boudiccaand you’re a commie, or a Poundland Lenin as Churchill’s grandson Nicholas Soames called the Shadow Chancellor. In Britain, our history has always been written from a perspective that defines the ruling class being heroic and everyone  being incidental. Deviate from that line and you’re committing treason. Yet that is precisely what is frequently committed when the same establishment creates heroes, in our name, through the honours system.   What level of treachery was David Cameron guilty of when he showered honours like confetti on his private staff as he walked out of Downing Street  How ungallant was Theresa May to attempt to bribe backbenchers like Edward Leigh with the offers of knighthoods and lordshipsthey backed her dodgy Brexit deal  You know Failing Grayling is going to get one when his disastrous Cabinet career is over, which is very soon. But these acts of gross nepotism happen all the time and go completely shyunchallenged. The Queen made her sons, Andrew and Edward, Knights of the Most Noble Order of the Garter despite one weeping like a homesick nursery toddler after five minutes in the Marines and the other spending  hours a day on the golf course. Sir Philip Green has finally been accused of being the sleazy, sexist, racist bullying spiv we always suspected he was, with serious calls for his shyknighthood to be taken away. But why did Tony Blair give him one in the first place  How come real heroes like World Cup winner Gordon Banks were strung along by the Honours Committee with nods and winks about a knighthood, only to die without one  A few days before Banks’ death, legendary actor Albert Finney passed away. The proud Salford lad had turned down a knighthood in , with these words: “I think the ‘Sir’ thing slightly perpetuates one of our diseases in England, which is snobbery.” How right he was. The same snobbery that dictates to the masses who the nation’s heroes are. And they’re iniably ones who shop at Harrods, not Poundland.

title: el chapo law agent tells
story: NewsEl Chapo: Law agent tells of obsession that led him to stop drug lordAmericas top drugs cop Jack Riley was set to retire before Mexicos notorious cartel boss escaped prison - and once that happened, the hunt was onShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsEl Chapo "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter a letime of service to his shycountry, Jack Riley sat in his corner office overlooking the Pentagon planning a retirement playing golf. As number two in America’s Drug Enforcement Administration, he had led the most successful operations in the agency’s history. The target of his obsessions were either dead or safely put away. But then in July , Riley’s nemesis, Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman, escaped. While being held in Mexico’s supposed maximum security Altiplano prison, the leader of the murderous Sinaloa Cartel – the world’s biggest drug-trafficking shyorganisation – fled through a mile-long tunnel built under his cell before riding away to freedom on a makesht motorbike. “I was going to retire until this d*** escaped,” Riley said.   Chapo had been his white whale, the object of an infatuation that sidelined shyeverything , including his family. “I love my we and kid, but I was never home for dinner,” said Riley. What followed was a very personal shyfour-year mission that this week ended with Chapo being put behind bars on US soil for le – and Riley finally retired. After a three-month trial in New York, jurors found the Mexican guilty on all  charges after six days of deliberation. They convicted the near legendary cartel boss of operating a continuing criminal enterprise, conspiracy to launder narcotics proceeds, international distribution of cocaine, heroin, marijuana and other drugs, and use of firearms.   He faces le in a “supermax” American jail in Florence, Colorado, known as the “Alcatraz of the Rockies” alongside Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, British shoe bomber Richard Reid and   conspirator Zacarias Moussaoui. The verdict brought a welcome end to Riley’s decades-long hunt for America’s most wanted man, who once offered an pound, bounty to anyone who brought him the DEA agent’s decapitated head. It is a fact Riley, , admits not only scared him but also “p***ed” him off. In , Riley was handed a transcript of a conversation wiretapped by his staff. It eavesdropped on Chapo’s men negotiating a price to kill him. “I saw a transcript, and it basically said, ‘What do you think Chapo would give us to shut him up and cut his head off.’ “The joke is, they talked about only , , which p***ed me off.  “What bothers me the most is I did exactly what that d*** wanted me to do. I got scared, and I started looking over my shoulder. And that’s what he intended.” Riley is the son of a hospital shypathologist and a nurse, and grew up in Chicago. His first jobs with the DEA had him working undercover as a s yuppie making cocaine deals. But he soon realised he wanted bigger fish – those who ran the operations. As he worked his way up through the ranks, he became involved in combating the Colombia drug trade, helping bring down Pablo Escobar in Medelliacuten and catch the leaders of the Cali cartel. Then when during the early s Chapo announced himself to the world by executing dozens of rivals and decapitating several Mexican cops, Riley’s interested piqued. “The images were seared into my soul. I never forgot the brutality or the name,” Riley said. Plus Chapo showed a gt for logistics no other cartel could match. At one point, he was called “El Rapido” because of his ability to move drugs from Mexico into the States within  hours. “Guzman was the most business-savvy son of a bitch who ever ran a criminal shyorganisation,” Riley said. His obsession with Chapo helped him become the head of the El Paso DEA office covering nearly one-third of the US-Mexico border. Upon his arrival, Riley made known his sole intention was “to get El Chapo under control”. His display of defiance did not go shyunnoticed. A sign reading, “Welcome Jack Reilly [sic]” was hung off a bridge just across the border in Mexico.  Weeks later as he drove along a deserted road, Chapo sent his men to give a warning. Riley was pursued at speeds of up to mph before he got out of his car, gun drawn expecting a firefight. But his pursuers shyinexplicably then sped off. Their job, however, was done. “That whole thing was just to scare the s*** out of me,” Riley said. However it only served to further cement his resolve. “I got p***ed off and said, ‘It’s either him or me,’” said Riley. “I’m a stubborn old Irish cop from Chicago. I’d put my money on me.” Despite a move back to his hometown, Riley refused to let his hunt for Chapo die. He began building a case in the Windy City targeting local gangs who worked for the cartel boss to stop the streets flooding with heroin. Under one roof Riley brought together the DEA, FBI, state troopers and police to chase the “choke-point guys” – the brokers who were buying in bulk from Chapo before then selling it on to the gangs. It opened huge resources to him including shywiretapping local criminals’ phones. “What really stands out is how stupid all these guys were,” Riley said. “On one call, [a dealer] is talking to Chapo’s guys in Mexico, and he says he thinks the ‘three letters’ [DEA] are onto us. So the guy says, ‘Don’t call me at this number anymore.’ Then he gives out his new number. We laughed our ass off in the office.”  Operation Strike Force was a huge success. Arrests and seizures rose, local drug lords fell and the busts netted millions in cash forfeitures. In , Chicago named Chapo Public Enemy No – and the fallout from Riley’s move surprised everyone, him included. The Mexican government was bombarded with calls from enraged shybusiness leaders demanding the drug lord’s arrest. “They screamed that Chapo was disgracing their country,” Riley said. Authorities in Mexico immediately changed their approach, offering new levels of shycooperation. They pledged to hunt down Chapo in the hills and working hand in glove with the DEA they closed in on him. US intelligence began shymonitoring the phones of those around him, so Chapo ordered his henchmen to dispose of their burner phones regularly, but many got lazy and didn’t. The US also used drones to carry out surveillance of suspected hideouts, hoping to snap an image of Chapo. The method led to several close calls – in one raid, Chapo escaped through a tunnel hidden beneath his bathtub – and shyultimately his capture in . A year after Riley’s announcement, they chased him to Mazatlaacuten and arrested him, without resistance, in his hotel room. A few months after his capture, however, Chapo was gone through that mile-long tunnel from his Mexican prison cell.  Although only ft ins, the drug lord compensated for his short stature as a giant in the Mexican underworld. He paid a reported poundmillion in costs and bribes to officials to remove more than , tonnes of earth to escape. It all added to the myth of El Chapo. “One of the reasons he’s been successful is he’s used the media. There are folk songs written about him,” Riley said. “There is the Robin Hood theory that he builds soccer fields and water purication. I’ve never seen any evidence of that, but he tries to paint himself that way. The only thing I know is he’s a stone-faced killer.” Riley, by now second in command at the DEA, had flown down a few days earlier to noty Mexican officials that Chapo was planning to escape. The alarm went ignored.  Then in late , they got another break. Officials suspected Chapo was heading to Los Mochis, a coastal town in Sinaloa. Surveillance images showed building crews reinforcing the front door on one house, and locals were overheard saying, “Papi is coming.” In the end, “burritos and porn are what did him in,” Riley said. It was January , when Mexican shyofficials saw a van leaving from a safe house late at night. Inside the vehicle, one of the men looked like Chapo. “They were going out for burritos and porn – who  would need both at that hour ” said Riley. After watching him , the Mexican marines moved in. Chapo escaped through the sewer and emerged, carjacking a driver before finally being apprehended. He was extradited to the US in .Riley, who is now retired, is happy his nemesis is facing le behind bars afterhis conviction.He has no love or admiration for Chapo. “He was on top for  years, has billions of dollars hidden – and he’s a second-grade dropout who can barely read and write and has to dictate love letters in prison. Explain it to me, ’cause I don’t get it. How did this f***ing mope become El Chapo ” Riley said. But sadly such was his business acumen that the drug lord has left a deadly legacy. Riley said: “All those routes he opened, all that fentanyl he shipped – he’s gonna kill our kids for years to come. This monster he built, it’s too big to fail now, thanks to him.” Fling Penn in jail for cartel bosss escape The cop credited with capturing Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman says Hollywood star Sean Penn should be in prison for allowing the drug lord to escape arrest. As Jack Riley, his DEA team and elite Mexican marines were poised to arrest the fugitive kingpin in October  in a rugged mountain hideout in his birthplace of La Tuna, their mission had to be aborted when the Oscar-winning actor suddenly appeared.  Just as the order was about to be given to move in, Penn and Kate del Castillo, a Mexican soap opera actress who had praised Chapo online, bizarrely arrived at the compound. The pair had arranged to met Chapo in secret for a film about his le before the Dead Man Walking star then published a gushing interview with the cartel boss in Rolling Stone magazine. Fearing the civilians would be caught in the crossfire, commanders ordered the marines to stand down. It gave Chapo the chance to escape. Riley, who inspired Breaking Bad’s Hank Schrader, is furious Penn has not faced prosecution. “Oh, my God. If I could get my hands on Sean Penn,” Riley said. “The people he put at risk because of that stunt. He should be in jail.”

title: mum mowed down cyclist after
story: NewsMum who took five or six bags of cocaine with vodka at party lost consciousness at wheel before mowing down cyclistSingle mum-of-four Kelly Sumner, , from Chorley in Lancashire, was  times over the drug-drive limit when she ploughed into respected IT consultant Stephen Derbyshire leaving him brain damagedShareCommentsByHannah Dawson:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsKelly Sumner has been jailed for three years "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who had taken five or six bags of cocaine  along with vodka and cider at a party lost consciousness at the wheel of her car before ploughing into a grandfather on a bike ride. Kelly Sumner has been locked up for three years after Stephen Derbyshire was left fighting for his le with a bone protruding from his skin and needing CPR. The -year-old IT consultant also suffered a le-changing brain injury and spinal fractures having been flung at least  feet into a lamp post. Sumner, , drove her Nissan Micra, without insurance, hours after staying up partying until am, reports Manchester Evening News . The mum-of-four from Chorley in Lancashire, sobbed in the dock as she was sentenced.   Bolton Crown Court earlier heard Mr Derbyshire was out on his bike on Lever Park Avenue in Horwich on June  last year when Sumner smashed into him. Prosecuting, Duncan Wilcock said Sumner was  times over the limit for benzoylecgonine - a metabolised form of cocaine - with mg per litre of blood. The cyclist was struck firstly on the bonnet in the middle, before continuing and hitting the windscreen of the car, he said. He ricocheted off the Micra, flew between  and  feet into the air and back into the lamp post behind him, spinning as he was thrown  degrees, finally landing on the pavement. Mr Derbyshire was treated by an off-duty nurse, a midwe and an off-duty surgeon, one of whom gave him CPR. A witness described seeing a bone protruding from Mr Derbyshires skin. He was taken by helicopter to Preston Royal Infirmary, the court heard.  Mr Derbyshire had to have blood drained from his chest which had to be drained was left with bruising to the brain and suffered multiple spine fractures. His we Patricia submitted an emotional statement to the court, in which she said she has had to become his full time carer. Mr Derbyshire now needs -hour supervision as he gets disorientated, the court heard. His daughter Leah choked up reading the statement on her mothers behalf. On June , , our lives were changed by a selfish, reckless act, she said. The defendant chose to take drugs and get behind a wheel. My husband did not have a choice. There is nothing that Stephen loves more than being at home with his family but this has been taking from him so cruelly. We feel as though we have been taken away from him. He has repeatedly said that he is not the man that I married.   We are at a time in our lives where we should be making plans for the future, now everything hangs in the balance. At one point he told me that he wanted to end his own le. She added: The defendant can leave here today and move on, but this will never change for us. None of us will ever be the same again. Mr Derbyshire, a grandfather to two young children, has to be helped sitting up, showering and dressing. Medics dont knowhell ever fully recover or be able to work again. Sumner, a cleaner, wept in the dock as the letter was read out.   In mitigation, Jon Close said Sumner had no previous convictions and that she was a single mother to four children, aged five to . Judge Timothy Stead condemned Sumners irresponsibility and disregard for safety. She was sentenced to three years for causing serious bodily harm by dangerous driving. She was also banned from the road. I am completely satisfied that the combination of fatigue and intoxication caused her to become unconscious whilst driving, Judge Stead said. The Derbyshire family said in a statement: If anything can come from this, we hope that this prosecution will deter anyone tempted to drive under the influence so that no family has to go through what we have had to over the last eight months.
